title: Trump calls Zelensky 'a dictator' after Ukraine leader said he was living in Russian 'disinformation space'
summary: Tensions soared between the two men on Wednesday after Trump, in an abrupt policy shift, has opened negotiations with Moscow and not Ukraine. After Trump lashed out, Zelensky said he will meet US envoy Keith Kellogg on Thursday and that he hopes for 'constructive' work with the US.

title: Heartbreaking day ahead for Israel, says Netanyahu
summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office, on Wednesday, announced it had the names of the hostages whose bodies Hamas is set to hand over, and had 'updated the families.' Netanyahu added in a separate statement: 'Tomorrow will be a very difficult day for the State of Israel – a heartbreaking day, a day of grief. We are bringing home four of our beloved hostages – fallen heroes.'

title: Germany's Merz vows tough migrant policy to stall AfD's rise
summary: The anti-immigration AfD – backed strongly by the inner circle of US President Donald Trump – looks set for its best-ever result of around 20%, according to current polling.

title: 'Europeans hold bitter memories of negotiating ceasefires with Putin'
summary: After the first day of negotiations between Russia and the US, without Ukraine or Europe, one thing is clear: Donald Trump is interested in a ceasefire but not in lasting peace, writes Le Monde's columnist, Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: PSG hammer Brest to reach Champions League last 16, Real Madrid knock Man City out
summary: Wednesday's 7-0 match is PSG's record-winning margin in a European game and the first time they have scored seven in the Champions League since they trounced Celtic 7-1 in November 2017. Meanwhile, former PSG superstar Kylian Mbappé struck a brilliant hat-trick for Champions League holders Real Madrid in a 3-1 win over Manchester City.

title: Glaciers are receding all over the world, at a rate of three Olympic swimming pools per second
summary: The Alps and Pyrénées are among the hardest-hit areas, having shed around 40% of their mass in 20 years, according to a study published in Nature on Wednesday.

title: Pope's health shows a 'slight improvement,' says Vatican
summary: Following Tuesday's statement that Pope Francis had been diagnosed with double pneumonia, the Vatican said his blood tests had shown positive results, and Giorgia Meloni said she had found him 'alert and responsive.'

title: Côte d'Ivoire's passion for Guinness World Records
summary: A young artist produced 132 portraits in five days, less than two months after a chef cooked for over 131 hours non-stop, all in front of public figures from all walks of Ivorian life.

title: China offers Hong Kong visas to wealthy Chinese in bid to stabilize the city
summary: The Special Administrative Region has developed a program to attract new residents, the majority of them from mainland China – who lack the liberal culture and tradition of the locals.

title: Digital archivists on the offensive against Trump's 'unprecedented' purge of government websites
summary: Executive orders signed by the new US president have led to the disappearance of thousands of pages, particularly those relating to climate change and equality policies. Several coordinated initiatives are attempting to preserve them.

title: Why did Ukraine reject Trump's mineral resources plan?
summary: Washington is demanding exclusive rights over Ukraine's 'mineral, oil and gas resources, ports, other infrastructure' in reimbursement for aid already paid out, according to a pre-contract revealed by the Daily Telegraph.

title: Where are Parisians from? For two-thirds of them, the answer is not Paris
summary: According to a study, the majority of people living in Paris were not born there – a phenomenon it has in common with most of France's major cities.

title: In joint interview, Trump outlines Musk's role as enforcer-in-chief
summary: Elon Musk told Fox News that 'one of the biggest functions of the DOGE [Department of Government Efficiency] team is just making sure that the presidential executive orders are actually carried out.'

title: Brazil's former president Bolsonaro rails against coup plot charges
summary: Jair Bolsonaro, who, along with 33 other suspects, was charged on Tuesday over an alleged 2022 coup attempt, has said he was the victim of fake accusations by an 'authoritarian regime.'

title: Egypt unearths first ancient royal tomb since Tutankhamun
summary: The ancient tomb of King Thutmose II, one of Tutankhamun's ancestors, who lived nearly 3,500 years ago, has been excavated by a joint Egyptian-British mission near the Valley of the Kings in southern Egypt.

title: Dolphins on Australian beach to be euthanized after mass stranding
summary: 157 false killer whales were found stranded on Tuesday on an isolated beach on the island of Tasmania.

title: Sweden's Supreme court throws out youth climate lawsuit backed by Greta Thunberg
summary: Sweden's Supreme Court dismissed a class action lawsuit filed in the name of some 300 people, including climate activist Greta Thunberg, but did not rule out trying a climate case if it were filed by an association.

title: What do Egyptian mummies smell like, and what can we learn from that?
summary: Thousands of years later, embalmed bodies still retain their scents. An international team of researchers has studied them to better understand the processes and products used.

title: France's interior minister promises progress for Muslims
summary: Bruno Retailleau hosted a meeting meant to address the difficulties related to the country's second-largest religion.

title: Highly dependent on the US market, Germany worries about Donald Trump's customs threats
summary: Washington's introduction of tariffs could further strain an already sluggish German economy. Since 2017, German manufacturers have been counting on the dynamic US market to diversify their outlets and supply sources.

title: Judge refuses to show beheading video at Islamic State kidnapping trial
summary: At the trial of five men accused of kidnappings in Syria, the court refused to show the video of the execution of American James Foley, requested by the prosecution.

title: How Trump is accelerating transformation of global trade
summary: By issuing an executive order that introduces reciprocal tariffs over the next six months, the US president is tearing down all the free-trade treaties negotiated at great length with countries such as South Korea, Mexico and Canada.

title: At the Centre Pompidou, Suzanne Valadon finds her rightful place in the art of her time
summary: After Metz, the Paris museum hosts an exhibition devoted to this figurative painter, with a different scenography and exceptional loans, including 'Joy of Life' (1911).

title: Japan plans a massive return to nuclear power in its energy roadmap
summary: The country, whose reactors have been restarting very gradually since 2015 following the Fukushima disaster, intends to return to 20% nuclear production by 2040, and aims to turn more widely to renewables, particularly solar, thanks to a breakthrough technology it believes it has mastered, said Philippe Escande, editorial writer at Le Monde.

title: Trump says federal government should 'take over' DC, backing congressional GOP push: 'Too much crime'
summary: The US president argued that he can't have sights of homelessness when he hosts foreign leaders in Washington. 'You just can't let that happen,' Trump said. 'You can't have tents on all your beautiful – your once magnificent plaza and lawns.'

title: Yoon becomes South Korea's first sitting president to go on criminal trial
summary: With Yoon in attendance as hearings opened Thursday, the courtroom was packed and there was heavy security around the building. The 64-year-old former prosecutor has been behind bars since he was arrested last month on charges of insurrection, for which he could be sentenced to life in prison or face the death penalty.

title: Cryolite, a rare mineral, is rekindling tensions between Greenland and Denmark
summary: A documentary estimates that exploitation of this 'white gold' has earned companies and the Danish state €54 billion. While the figures are disputed by economists, they're fueling pro-independence rhetoric in Nuuk.

title: Sri Lanka train derails after smashing into elephants
summary: No passengers were injured but six animals were killed in the island's worst wildlife accident, police said. Killing or harming elephants is a criminal offence in Sri Lanka, which has an estimated 7,000 wild elephants, with the animals considered a national treasure, partly due to their significance in Buddhist culture.

title: Team Kleenex: What if we (finally) accepted crying in the workplace?
summary: While shedding tears has long been associated with weakness, things are changing. Crying allows one to express something they cannot put into words.

title: Souleymane Cissé, one of the fathers of African cinema, dies at 84
summary: The great Malian director, twice awarded at Cannes, died in Bamako on Wednesday at the age of 84. He had held a press conference there that very morning to promote African cinema.

title: Delta offers $30,000 to passengers in crashed plane
summary: Making the offer on Wednesday, the American airline insisted that 'this gesture does not affect the rights' of passengers.

title: Ukrainians in shock after Trump's virulent attacks on Zelensky
summary: The US president accused Kyiv of being behind the war and called him a 'dictator.' This escalation stunned the population and the authorities alike and plunged the country a little further into the unknown.

title: After Trump's attacks on Zelensky, Europeans seek to influence upcoming negotiations
summary: On the sidelines of a second mini-summit in Paris, European leaders expressed concern that America would quickly give in to Russian demands. Emmanuel Macron could be going to Washington as early as Monday.

title: Hamas hands over bodies of four hostages to Israeli army
summary: The militants said it was handing over the remains of the wife and two children of Yarden Bibas, who was released on February 1, as well as the body of Oded Lifshitz, who was 83 years old when he was abducted on October 7, 2023. The bodies have yet to be identified.

title: Andrius Kubilius: 'The US now talks about peace but without strength'
summary: In an interview with 'Le Monde,' the European commissioner for defense and former Lithuanian prime minister expressed his concern about the United States' turn on Ukraine as well as Russia's intentions.

title: US appeals court upholds block on Trump's order to end birthright citizenship
summary: One of the executive orders Donald Trump made when he took power, it tries to redefine the 14th Amendment to the US Constitution, which decrees that anyone born on US soil is a citizen.

title: 'A dictator without elections': Watch Trump's attacks against Zelensky
summary: After initial attacks published on his Truth Social platform on Wednesday, the US president reiterated his comments during a speech in Miami.

title: India's ruling party takes control of Delhi
summary: Rekha Gupta, 50, of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was sworn in as Delhi's chief minister after a historic election victory, marking the party's first control of the capital in over two decades.

title: After three years of war, where do Ukrainian and Russian forces stand?
summary: It's been three years since the start of Moscow's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. While 2024 saw a Ukrainian breakthrough into Russian territory and the bogging down of the front lines, negotiations have now begun between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin, but without Ukraine or Europe.

title: France returns its only military base to Côte d'Ivoire
summary: The 43rd BIMA marine infantry battalion's camp was renamed on Thursday the Camp Thomas d'Aquin Ouattara, after the Ivorian army's first chief of staff.

title: France adopts 'one of the most ambitious' laws on PFAS
summary: French MPs have adopted a bill to protect the public from the risks associated with forever chemicals. It bans their use in three product categories and imposes a charge on industrial water discharges under the 'polluter pays' principle.

title: Spanish court fines ex-football chief €10,800 over non-consensual kiss
summary: Luis Rubiales has been found guilty of sexually assaulting the footballer Jenni Hermoso after Spain’s victory at the Women's World Cup final in 2023. But the court acquitted him and the three others accused of the charge of coercion in the case.

title: At the IS kidnapping trial, former hostage Edouard Elias delivers harrowing testimony
summary: On Wednesday, one of the four French journalists held hostage in Syria gave a thorough account of the 11 months he spent in the terrorist group's 'killing machine.' He also officially identified the voice of one of his torturers, Frenchman Mehdi Nemmouche.
